author: {'steamid': '76561197997724945', 'num_games_owned': 4613, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1461790581}
review:
First of all, I have to say that this is the first time I play a game of the Neptunia series. I always heard great many things about this franchise, [i]not only because of the half naked females of course[/i], but also for its rather interesting setting that tends to appeal to gamers and the huge amount of customization and turn-based combat that these games tend to provide and so, because of that, I decided I’d give this one a chance. So far, for someone who had never played a game of this series before, I must say that I’m really enjoying the universe so far and I plan to play the other games as well.

[u][b]Story:[/b][/u]

[b]Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart[/b] takes place in the world of [i]Gamarket[/i], a place where games are released at an unrelenting pace, which is also divided into four different nations, each with its own rulling goddess, or CPU - Console Patron Unit. These nations are constantly at war with each other, seeking to expand their control and convert the faith of the citizens into power in the form of shares. 

Thanks to the evil plot of a certain mysterious character, a chain of unfortunate events starts to unfold, which results in the breakdown of the Sharicite, the physical representation of the peoples shares and the CPUs power. This forces the four goddesses to unite themselves in order to save the world of Gamarket. While I assume that this will feel like a very generic storyline to some people, I like it and find it rather interesting and each of the characters is unique and has its own personality.

[u][b]Gameplay:[/b][/u]

I think I wouldn’t be mistaken if I said that the game is split 50/50 by two very different genres. It is a [b]mixture of a visual novel with tactical/strategy RPG elements[/b], such as party turn-based combat. 

The [u]visual novel part of the game[/u] is pretty much just dialogue, which is voice acted for the most part. You’ll spend a lot of time interacting with the main protagonist, Noire, the CPU who presides over Lastation, one of the regions of Gamarket. Visually I really like the art design, but I understand some people will find it abhorrent, but those people will most likely not even read this, so yeah. That said, some of the characters are pretty much half naked, and even though I have no problem with that, I’m sure some people won’t find it appealing. The conversations are also full of suggestive themes, puns and sexual jokes.

Once you unlock the Lastation city screen, you’ll be able to do tons of stuff here including, selling, buying and crafting items, you can also talk to various different characters, take on missions or go and talk to Noire on her room. On Noire’s room, there is also some sort of dating/visual novel aspect in the form of customizing her room and answering to requests of the citizens with her, which will eventually unlock some extra scenes. Still, if you don’t want any of that you can completely ignore it. If you go to your Mission HQ, you can play new missions and simulations. Simulations consist on replaying old missions to get more rewards. You can also choose if you want to go straight for the main story missions or take on some side missions which, despite not providing any sort of story, they still give you some nice rewards.

As for the [u]RPG side of the game[/u], it comes in different ways such as customizing your characters with many different weapons and pieces of equipment and loot that you get either by killing enemies or completing missions. The combat is presented in a chibi art style, which contrasts with the visual design of the rest of the game and I find it be rather lovely. Combat itself is turn-based, which means that in each turn your characters can move and attack once, and movement is grid based. Still, you can move before or after performing an offensive action. When choosing an enemy to attack, you’ll be able to see how much damage you’ll do and its accuracy, as well as the enemy’s counter rate and expected damage. By killing enemies you’ll get loot and experience points which will allow you to level up your characters. Combat also rewards you for placing units next to each other when using special abilities, by improving the relationship between the two characters and granting you points to use more powerful skills.

Initially you’ll only control one character, the main protagonist - Noire (Black Heart), but soon enough more will join your cause. Even though I enjoy a lot games with turn-based combat, I do think that this is one of the weakest points of the game, albeit still a good one. Combat can get somewhat repetitive, especially if you plan on playing every single mission and simulation more than once. Some of the levels in which you fight offer some variety such as traps like electrified fences and floor plates, or the addition of height/verticality.

[h1]Final Verdict:[/h1][list]
[*]Tons of customization
[*]Lovely visual design
[*]Catchy soundtrack - even though I don’t understand the lyrics
[*]Robust turn-based combat system
[*]Storyline is a mixed bag - it might feel generic to some but I like it and find it rather interesting
[*]Funny dialogue, albeit somewhat cringe at times
[*]Framerate capped at 28
[/list]
Hyperdevotion Noire lets you experience a visually appealing, charming and funny story that takes place in a [i]”gamer friendly world”[/i]. It has a pretty solid combat system that offers some replay value with different combinations and because of that, I recommend this game to both fans of visual novels and SRPGs. Needless to say that it this is must check for fans of the Neptunia series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001221086', 'num_games_owned': 2637, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 3997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1677, 'last_played': 1469333391}
review:
[h1]Indroduction[/h1]

Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart takes the series familiar CPUs in a new direction once again, this time taking the series into the turn-based, tactical role-playing strategy realm.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart sets itself apart from the previous Hyperdimention Neptunia games available on Steam in several ways. The number one way is the game is now more about tactics and strategy than it previously had been. Using the terrain to your advantage is one of the strategy elements. Each weapon type in the game has its own hit box. For example, spears can hit two squares away but can’t hit a higher or lower elevation. On the other hand, swords are limited to one square away but can hit one level above or below.  A hit from the side or the back will do more damage than hitting a character from the front and also reduces their chance to counter attack. You need to plan your moves out carefully as all characters have a limited amount of mobility. For instance, you cannot walk through an enemy or go over a wall with a higher level than your jump score will allow you to scale. This means you can easily get yourself trapped in a corner if you don’t plan your route carefully. In addition to having to figure out where you want to end up once you make your single move for that turn, you need to pay attention to the route your character plans to take to get there. Your characters are a bit like Lemmings that will blindly fling themselves over ledges or walk into traps if you tell them to. Changing the direction your character is facing allows you to adjust their route to help avoid those situations. Just because you dodged a trap doesn’t mean it won’t get you though. If you stop next to a trap, an enemy will often use its knockback attack to try to push you into the trap setting it off.  As you can see, there is a lot of planning, strategy and tactics involved in this game but there is even more than that to consider.

Each character in the game has its own abilities. Using these abilities, regardless of the intended target, will cause any characters that are one square away from the user to boost that ability’s effect. This means that if you cluster five of your characters in a plus shape and have the one in the middle cast a buff or long range attack, the other four characters will “peck” the caster enhancing the effect and boosting their Lily Ranks in the process. The higher the Lily Rank, the more effective the boost will be. You may be thinking that a good strategy would be to cluster your units and let the enemy come to you. There is a drawback to that plan though; some abilities can hit multiple targets. Instead of hitting just one of your characters with their strong attack, it’s possible they could hit multiple or all of them. Now you can see the tactics in this game are quite complex and not to be taken lightly. There is one more thing to cover on the tactics side though.

Elements are introduced as a way to play a pseudo rock, paper, scissors game. One element is stronger against another element but in turn is weaker to yet another element. Some chests found in the levels can only be opened using an elementally infused normal attack (skills and abilities usually have no effect on objects). Having characters with each of the elements available will aid you in looting each of the levels effectively assuming the characters have the ability (jump score, etc.) to reach the chest before the rest of your crew either kills off the enemies, or the enemy you were saving alive dies to a counter attack.  There are still more tactical elements to this game, but I will leave those to you to discover.

Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart features a crafting system. As you kill various monsters and complete missions you will aquire drops. These drops allow you to fabricate various things you will need to survive. Better weapons and items can all be crafted. This is where the strategy comes into play. Each piece of equipment has different effects. Sometimes you must make a trade off. To increase your movement range, you may have to reduce your defense a smidge. For the most part, you only need to craft a new item once for it to then appear in the store. This means you don’t have to worry too much about tracking down something you don’t currently have enough of to make another of the same. Buying from the store has its advantages too. Whenever you make a purchase you get Sim Points. Consider them like customer loyalty points of sorts. You will use these points to upgrade Noire’s house. The various things you buy will be added to her home and you can talk to them to get tips or fun conversations. You can also craft and name your own games within the game. Games are an upgrade that allows you to pick and choose what perks you want based on the elements that went into making the game.

Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart isn’t set in Gameindustri like the Hyperdimention Neptunia series, it is set in Gamarket. The four CPU Goddesses are all vying for total control of Gamarket. The series, if you are completely unfamiliar with it, is a satire of the current game market. Each of the CPUs represents one of the major console brands. Noire of Laststation, who as the title suggests is the star of the game much to Neptune’s displeasure, tries to end the fighting by listening to a strangers suggestion. This leads all of the Shares (think of them as likes/upvotes/retweets) in the land to disappear leaving the CPUs powerless and Gamarket in a political power vacuum.  I won’t spoil the story by going further, but it is quite in-depth. Much like previous games in the series, the gameplay is bookended by long expositional scenes. These are often cute, humours and quite enjoyable. It can also be quite fun trying to figure out who the next General pays homage to. For example, one of them named Lid, is a Solid Snake reference. She likes hiding in cardboard boxes and using air ducts to move around. 

The art style in this game might be a little off-putting to some at first, but eventually it grows on you even if you had doubts going in. The Anime style characters are now Chibi during game play and resume their usual Anime form when talking to each other between missions. Chibi means they have oversized heads and tiny bodies. The style actually suits the way the battlefield works, and I think that having normal characters would have likely looked a bit weird there. Being Chibi lets you see their face clearly so you know who it is you are controlling just by looking at them. If you are being off put by the Chibi art style and plan on skipping it for solely that reason, you are doing yourself a great disservice.

Overall, Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart is a great turn-based, tactical role-playing strategy game. It is reminiscent of Final Fantasy Tactics so if you enjoyed that take on the Final Fantasy series, you will more than likely enjoy this take on the Hyperdimention Neptunia series. Current fans will not be disappointed either!

[list]Pros:

[*]The game looks good. Even though my system barely meets the requirements it looks great
[*]Tactical elements work really well
[*]Crafting system makes having to redo levels to grind Lily Ranks more enjoyable
[*]Sim Noire gives you are reason to spend your money rather than horde it
[*] Multiple difficulty settings

Cons:

[*]There is a ton of DLC at launch
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197978705200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 250, 'playtime_forever': 1925, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1925, 'last_played': 1461691193}
review:
Now you've been following Gamindustri for quite awhile, but have you ever heard of Gamarket? If you're a long-time fan of the Neptunia franchise, then you're aware that there are many dimensions. In Gamarket, Noire rules. Thanks to the help of her 18 generals, she has defeated the other CPUs, and is well on her way to achieving total domination...well... was anyway. It seems that she has had a temporary setback, and it's up to you, the player, to get her back on her feet. With your help, Noire just might be able to unite Gamarket. Hey, you might even get the opportunity to win over the Goddess of Lonely Hearts. I wish I was joking about that last part.

When designing a spin-off, it's important to consider the intended audience. While it makes sense that fans of the Neptunia RPGs can also enjoy other genres, there has to the right balance of depth and fun-factor, or else the developer risks pushing those fans away. In this regard, [i]Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart[/i] is a success. It delivers a thoroughly competent S-RPG, without drowning players in stats and a multitude of convoluted sub-systems. The "nendoroid" art-direction suits the game-play portions really well. The visuals help set the game apart from other entries in the franchise. 

[h1]The Game[/h1]
Typically, your battle strategy is going to revolve around something I like to call the "PECK" system. Whenever a heroine performs an ability while next to an ally, she gets a little kiss on the cheek. This reduces the cost of the move, boosts its damage, and awards meter for performing special attacks. Naturally, you'll want to group up as often as possible, but this will make the party more susceptible to AOE spells and the like. It's a trade-off you'll learn to respect, as your foes will take every opportunity, to do a lot of damage all at once. Keep in mind also that almost every heroine has one or two buff abilities. There will be times when your allies make a move, and there aren't any nearby enemies to attack. The game is subtly telling you to prepare for the next round. Although, I can't say that I appreciate that lily-ranks are tied to PECK. You'd better be looking forward to a ginormous amount of smooching, if you want to get all of the achievements.

Early on you'll decide the elemental-affinity of the CPUs and Generals you recruit. Almost all monsters are strong or weak to certain elements. Outside of a few exceptions, your party will always consist of at least four members. Since there are four elements, it's only logical to use the entire spectrum. Hammering this point home is the fact that most treasure-chests are locked, and only the right elementally-aligned character can open them. As with other Neptunia games, most of the treasures are materials used to craft weapons and armor. 

The battles themselves tend to have different objectives beyond "kill all of the monsters". The maps can have trapped floors, varying heights, and a host of other aspects to account for. The heroines can even lift and throw objects, just in case they need to reach higher-ground. Thankfully, traversing the map never becomes something akin to a puzzle game.  You're not going to spend several minutes messing around with geo-panels, geo-blocks, or all of those other geo-whatsits. A lot of battles in HD Noire have gimmicks, but for the most part, they're clever and offer a nice touch of variety.

The difficulty of this game is fairly open-ended. While you're free to choose a level of difficulty, at the beginning, you'll have better luck making things more challenging by avoiding the optional quests. The story battles award enough experience to keep everyone at a reasonable level anyway. You can also use weaker party-members, or avoid certain equips and abilities. All told, HD Noire is kind-of simplistic, but it's really entertaining. Although, enemies not being affected by traps can take a little while to get used to.

[h1]The Story[/h1]
When it comes to the Neptunia franchise, its greatest strengths tend to lie in its storyline and characters, or at least I think so. While the Candidates don't make an appearance in HD Noire, the four Goddesses are joined by the aforementioned 18 generals. Each chapter usually involves putting a stop to whatever the generals are planning, and then recruiting them to your party. It's a predictable setup, but it has some amusing moments. However, there are times where the story feels rushed, or certain events happen just to draw everyone into a fight. I don't mind, since it's nice to have boss-fights that are unique and interesting.

The biggest problem with the story is you, the player, aka the secretary. While you never take an active role in battle, you're present in nearly every story scene. There's also a "Sim-Noire" mode where you purchase furniture, and answer questions that best align with Noire's personality. I have no why this game needed such a blatant player-insert character. Essentially all you do is kiss Noire's behind, until the game decides that you should do or say something inspirational. 

Awhile back I played through another game by Sting Entertainment called [i]Dungeon Travelers 2[/i]*. The fan-service levels in this D-RPG are off the charts. Even the monsters look like scantily-clad women. Anyway, you play the role of a young man who forms a battle-party, to hunt and research these monsters. Despite being the only male character in the game, and getting involved in enough harem incidents to blot out the sun, you're still a well-designed player-insert. You also show a high-level of aptitude when it comes to adventuring. It's nice that you handle the many, many lewd situations, in a intelligent and respectful manner as well. By comparison, your role in HD Noire is a liability. 

I don't like to draw comparisons, but with DT2, I had every expectation that my eyes would roll out of my head and then around the world. As it turns out, I was pleasantly surprised by how well-done the character-writing was. HD Noire is too basic and predictable. The 18 Generals are mostly fodder for sight gags and quirky speech patterns. Noire aside, the CPUs don't recieve any development, and Neptune is more grating than ever. The player-insert is flat and uninteresting, but everyone thinks he's handsome and agreeable, so I guess it's supposed to work out? The relationship between you and Noire is a mess, and does nothing but induce vomiting. This is one of the rare benefits of having an extended multiverse. What happens in Gamarket, stays in Gamarket, and thank goodness for that.

[h1]The Conclusion[/h1]
Storyline aside, [i]Hyperdevotion Noire: Goddess Black Heart[/i] is a fun experience. It encapsulates all of the elements that make up a quality S-RPG. Granted, it doesn't have the depth and customization that will appeal to the most hardened of veterans. In a way this can also be considered a positive, but maybe it's just me. My most-played S-RPG is [i]Shining Force 2[/i], partly because it's so easy to just pick up and play. In short, this game has most of everything one could ask for in a spin-off. Just don't be afraid to press the start button to skip cut-scenes, especially whenever the subject of conversation is you.

*It's honestly one of the better dungeon-crawlers that I've played.
